Title: Why are eigenvalues of nilpotent matrices equal to zero?
Content: If $A$ is a $ \displaystyle  10 \times 10 $ matrix such that $A^{3} = 0$ but $A^{2}  \neq 0$ (so A is nilpotent) then I know that $A$ is not invertible, but why does at least one eigenvalue of $A$ have to be equal to zero? How would one show that all eigenvalues of $A$ are equal to zero?
AcceptedAnswer: If $v$ is a non-zero eigen vector corresponding to an eigenvalues $\lambda$ we have, by definition, $Av=\lambda v$. Then $A^2v= A( Av)= A(\lambda v)= \lambda^2v$. It easily follows that $\lambda^n$ is an eigenvalue for $A^n$ but the latter is the zero matrix, for which all eigenvalues are zero,   hence $\lambda=0$.
